All of them come from humble lifestyles and a few would be studying or applying for some kinda govt. jobs, so they have a lot of knowledge about a lot of things. And they aren't always stuck into their phones so they know what's happening in their surroundings.

They bring fact to reality that "Language isn't a barrier of knowledge". They have political and economical understandings, facts and view points of the country.

The taxi driver / guide - Mr. Khan, Kudos! for being the guy who you are. This purely shows how humble and nice Indians are rest assured knowledgeable. He had a smile and did his job and beyond. Many comments said "cute broken English", and as true as it was everyone understood what he said and he didn't shy aways from speaking and sharing more, and for that I'm sure people across the world watching this video would feel how warm Indians are if you genuinely want to know us. 

Even the random taxi guy outside Palladium mall associated Indira Gandhi to Italy;  I'm sure if you get a youtuber out on the streets asking the richer and so called educated youth this particular question, they wouldn't know it.

Mr. Khan, I hope to travel in your cab someday, I'd definitely buy you a tea and love to talk to you.

In fact my father was manager at The Taj Mahal Hotel in the 1950s where he met Mr Ramanathan, President of Singapore between 1999-2011, who was previously (1982) chairman of The Straits Times.  At that time Mr Ramanathan was not well known and he was visiting Bombay in a personal capacity.  So my father took him around Bombay and they became close friends.  
I had also gone to St Don Bosco School in Matunga, where the church is covered with beautiful marble imported from Italy.  I believe it was Fr. Aurelius Maschio who helped build that beautiful church.

I haven't been to India since 1996. I was a woman alone, traveling with a backpack and Lonely Planet Guidebook, and the changes I've seen via videos such as yours are really amazing. One thing that strikes me since then is the growth of wealth in that country. It looks like some of it has trickled down and a more prosperous middle class is rising. What shocked me the most about India was all the homeless living on the streets, making cardboard shelters by rivers in the countryside and everywhere they weren't driven off. I didn't realize I was seeing a preview of what's now becoming a familiar sight in America -- homeless people everywhere. The economy has shifted again towards places with lots of excess people who will work in factories for pennies, relocating wealth once again. I'd go back if I could, but NOT alone and with a backpack at my age of 75.

Hi Brother,
I am from Sitapur (Uttar Pradesh). I watched your video in January 2025 and liked this place very much. I had thought to visit this place with my wife and daughter. Finally in May 2025 I got a chance to visit this place with my family. 
Harsil is 750km away from Sitapur. Harsil is very beautiful surrounded by snowy mountains. Very cold weather in Harsil. You will see so many waterfalls on the way from uttarkashi to Harsil.
Guys you should visit this place once in a lifetime. People are very friendly.

This video is very touching and appreciated.  In 2006, at the age of 19, i travelled from my home in the Appalachian mountains (USA) to Uttarakhand and spent 1 month in the region.  I stayed in a tiny village called Lata that looked very similar to the Harsil valley.  It is somewhat close to Josimath, so a bit farther southeast along the mountain chain and adjacent to Nanda Devi National Park.  It was the first time I had been outside of my own country and I felt so incredibly welcomed and taken care of by the people of this region that it still blows my mind to this day. Kasol has its own Charm. It is small Manali is Big like a City Kasol is still very small. Parvati Valley is divine & it is a Christmas Small Village like Earlier but right now it's very Polluted & Full of Garbage & alot of Buildings obviously because of Tourists but Manali has still a Different Vibe. If you want to go to a Hike towards the Higher Village towards Old Manali opposite of Club Road. There Buy Hashish or Charas which will be premium it is of a Higher Altitude Village & Manali Hash will be awesome. Kasol is still a more Cosmic but Manali is a Bit More Real you see alot of Police & Roads & Highways & People but Kasol is a small Hamlet in Himalayas with a very pretty river Side earlier it was Heaven till 2017 but now it's very Damaged lost its charm but it is still a good place to go with Family also because Now it's Safe it was Safe Earlier although anything can happen anytime but still Parvati Valley is Cosmic Spiritual Magical Happy but very Mysterious on a whole another like a Cosmic Himalayas Mountains Movie with Aliens Something about Himalayas of India which makes them very Cosmic & Mysterious

Every time I go in these mountains, I try to find out what kind of things I can carry from home from the hotel or homestay I'm staying it. most of the time they know if there's something not available easily. Like once, when I visited Sissu Valley the hotel owner told me they need a few over the counter medication. Stuff that they have to go to Manali or Kullu to get. Sometimes they even ask truck drivers delivering supplies to get it from some distant towns. We had carried quite a few medicines for the village. If you're traveling light, and you can afford a few thousand bucks more in terms of supply, pls carry it. It always helps them out. Those people are super helpful especially when it comes to surviving in the mountains. And just like this, they welcome you in their shops and homes without hesitation.
